title: On 25 September 2019, what will be Venezuela's annual inflation rate according to Bloomberg's Cafe Con Leche Index?
preds: Since it's been far less than 50,000% so far it shouldn't change that much more.
As at the moment the inflation rate 27 900 % and there are only few days left, the first option seems very likely.

While waiting for the next "Cafe Con Leche" update; thought It might be a good idea to create an alternative index. This is based on the published price, for the Economist Magazine (based on the prices printed on the magazine cover).  The Comparison is for prices from the June 18th, 2016 issue and the current (Sept. 14) issue. Based on a simplistic 1 item comparison,, there seems to be higher levels of inflation in Brazil, Canada and the U.K. than in Venezuela ...........Suspect that there may be additional factors in specific item prices beyond the general price levels in a country? Country......................2016.............current...
Argentina:.................$7.00..................$7.00
Brazil:....................R$36.90..............R$49.95
Canada...................C$7.99................C$9.99
Chile:..................Ch$5,000............Ch$5,000
UK:..............................5.00.....................5.99 Pound
US:............................$7.99...................$7.99
Venezuela:...........Bs99.00...............Bs99.00
According to Bloomberg, it's currently 27,900% on Sep 13 2019.  It is highly unlikely to go above 50,000%.

Yesterday the price was updated to 14000 Bolivars and there are only two weeks for the deadline. A 50,000% inflation will require coffee to reach a price of 24950 Bolivars in two weeks, and during the last months monthly inflation has been around 30% (and we are talking about half a month at most).

September 7 and as per index the inflation rate 39,900%. There is only 5 months left in the year and based on blooomberg;s inflation rate 6 months ago which is  Annual Inflation Rate
2,400% The rate will be safely below the last bucket's maximum. Inflation has been beaten in Venzuela, contrary to the hysterical Western media and even the IMF.
Deferring to the crowd and experts.
Political situation seems to have stabilized slightly and the inflation rate seems to have leveled off around 300,000% for now.

4,000 bolivar price increase this week.
Risk: coffee Shop can post any price they prefer on the closing date, for any reason.
Finally the cafe owner adjusted the price in line with the real rate. Now it will be fixed for a couple of weeks, so inflation rate will be 29,000%.
Going lower as the hyperinflation seems to be burning itself out.
Based on current value and timeframe of change.
Current annual rate in June was 35900%

The cafeteria takes time to adjust, about 4 or 5 weeks. Based on the free USD FX rate, it will go to Bs 14,000 next time that the price is revised, which would be about 30,000%, unless dramatic, even worse, change in conditions (10%).

Current base price for the 1 yr rate in the Bloomberg index is 25, the price on Sept. 26, 2018 was 50.  For the index to maintain the current 38,000 inflation rate the price of the coffee will need to double from 9,000 to 18,000 Bolivars.  Of course, there is no reason that would prevent the shop from doing something similar, if they chose to.
Follows current trend ; no economic or political trends that would disrupt the trend

I am significantly revising down my expectations based on the trends in the index over the last three months (thank you @nigster for your ongoing calculations [1]).  The index peaked towards the end of 2018, and inflation rates have continued to fall. I remain confused by the gap between the Bloomberg index inflation rates (<50k%) and other reports putting inflation at over 250k% [2] or even closer to 10 million  [3].  While the levels vary vastly, all reports suggests that inflation has come down since the spring.  So, it seems unlikely that the price of coffee will shoot up to over 25,000 bolivars to make even the second bucket (50-100k %) in the next six weeks. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/873159
[2] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-economy/venezuela-inflation-rate-ticks-up-despite-liquidity-restrictions-idUSKCN1UY25Y
[3] https://www.cnbc.com/2019/08/02/venezuela-inflation-at-10-million-percent-its-time-for-shock-therapy.html

Some reservations regarding the bakery in east Caracas.  Is it a pro-Maduro or an anti-Maduro cafe?  Surely the cafe must know that it an object of a Venezuelan inflation index.  The "cafe con leche" index is not a real inflation measure.  It can be influenced by many factors other than Venezuelan inflation rates.  For example, is the "cafe con leche" a profitable item?  Or, Is "cafe con leche" a loss leader? Is the cafe, as a whole, profitable? Or is the cafe operating at a loss?  Is the "cafe con leche" an important part of the cafe's revenue and profits, or not? Recent reports indicate the US dollar is again circulating in Venezuela.  Are foreigners, spending US dollars a high percentage of customers in the cafe? If so, what percentage of sales in the cafe are in dollars?   The concern is that if the cafe is anti-Maduro, and the majority of sales are in dollars, the price could easily be manipulated, at the last minute, to indicate a higher rate of inflation.
Sitting at 44900 now, with 5 weeks to go = )
It stands at some 40000% now, and with new sanctions announced it is not likely to fall.
Historical trends, political uncertainty and Trump!
Pro rating the Bloomberg coffee price trend.

Since I last looked at the question since weeks ago, the inflation rate has just been plummeting (albeit from 81,000% to 44,900% today). It is looking like their hyperinflation spiral has entered its burnout phase as people simply stop using the currency in favor of other things like the dollar like we saw a few years ago in Zimbabwe.  The government could still do something to screw up the currency more but my guess is the inflation rate falls from its current rate to a still astronomical but lower rate.
Aug 3 it is stable at 34,900% and has been stable for a month at that rate.
It seems the USD is devaluating faster than initially expected. The index has not changed, but my guess is that it will do so next week, to BS 11,000. We can be closer to 50K% to 100K% than expected.
Subject of course to the fact that the maduro/guaido conflict could make things worse

Here's the index: https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2016-venezuela-cafe-con-leche-index/ Here's the economic forecast: https://www.focus-economics.com/countries/venezuela And here's the Venezuelan strategy to boost oil production temporarily to help stabilize their economy: https://www.hydrocarbonprocessing.com/news/2019/07/venezuela-to-blend-domestic-imported-oil-to-keep-exports-afloat It probably won't work long term, but might help keep inflation somewhat in check until the target date. Maybe.

The IMF predicted 1.37 million %. Which is just risible. Venezuela's 2018 Inflation to Hit 1.37 Million Percent, IMF Says
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-10-09/venezuela-s-2018-inflation-to-hit-1-37-million-percent-imf-says The current inflation rate is just under 50 000% but the increases have plataued. If current trends continue and there is only 2-3 months to September 25 it will remain at this figure. There isn't time for the current figure to change significantly enough for the top 3 buckets and only enough for the bottom 2 buckets.

Base price on 26 Sept 2018 = 50. Need to know the price on 25 Sept 2019 in order to determine the 1 yr inflation Rate. How to to do that?
- current price (17 July 2019 is 7,000)
- noticed that since 30 Jan 2019 the price trend looks linear rather than geometric.
- check linear rate of change between:
----- 30 Jan (1,700) and 6 Mar (2,800) = 220 / week ((2,800 - 1,700) / 5 weeks).
----- 30 Jan (1,700) and 17 July (7,000) = 221 / week ((7,000 - 1,700) / 24 weeks).
- Yep.  Price increase became linear around end of Jan 2019 Forecast 1 yr inflation rate on 25 Sept 2019:
(7,000 + (221 * 10 ten weeks left til 25 Sept 2019) - 50 (base price on 26 Sep 2018)) / 50 (original base price) Or approx. 18,300%
Keepin’ It real on the low side.
With devaluation im rapidly revising former estimates.

The free dollar actually revalued this week. The cup of coffee increased in the range I expected (in fact, lower than I expected), so I'm adjusting more to the lower band. No indications for a change in politics, unfortunately, yet.

Inflation seems to have peaked, but is still at extreme highs. M2 has grown but the growth rate in M2 has fallen as well. I dont expect the inflation to level off just yet, they are still in massive problems, namely the deterioation in their oil industry is still crushing their economy. According to the study on hyperinflation "On the Measurement of Zimbabwe’s Hyperinflation" they conclude that the average hyperinflation period is around 20 months. Mind you with huge uncertainty given the very little data i.e. about 25-30 hyperinflation incidences in the 21st and 20th century and with uncertainty in gathering data. According to the con leche index, hyperinflation "began" around november 2018 - december 2018, given that the price doubled from 195 to 400 bolivars, a rapid increase. That is about 6-7 months of hyperinflation, vastly less than the average hyperinflation period of 20 months. Furthermore, even if inflation did suddenly drop to 1-2% per month, the annual inflation would still be higher. Thus, for the annual inflation rate to become less than 50,000%, we need to go from hyperinflation to deflation, which i dont believe is impossible but highly unlikely. The trend in annual inflation rate is slowing down, thus, i do think that it will grow, but i dont think it will in a matter of a few months grow beyond 100,000%. It is quite likely it does, but the most likely scenario given the current trend, the lower growth in M2 i expect inflation to be between 50,000-100,000% by september. 100,000-200,000 will be my next most likely scenario and will have the highest probability. My probability estimates for each "category" will be weighted with the crowd estimates - EDIT: I did weight the estimates, but the estimates where i had highest conviction i put more emphasis on my own perception than the crowd, giving more weight to my own estimate.

I was planning on getting in to some reading on historical limits of hyperinflation, and a general vibe of the political situation and chances of change in the next 12 weeks. But I'm making my prediction without that - because simply looking at the numbers would make >50,000% almost impossible. My thinking...
- This is a 1 year inflation rate at 25 Sep - so the starting point is 50 Bolivars on Sep 26 (*not* the 10 Bolivars that is the current start of the 12mo inflation chart)
- For inflation to be above 50,000% on Sep 25 would require a coffee to cost 25,000 - 3.8x what it is today (6,500)
- Looking at a rolling 3mo price increase, the last 6 months have been 18x, 10x, 6.6x, 2.9x, 2.75x, 2.2x - so a 3.8x increase would be a huge change based on that trend
- Simply fitting a polynomial trend to the data from Sep 26 2018 out to Sep 25 2019 gives us a final price of ~8,300 (the R-squared is 0.971 - I realise economics and geopolitics isn't maths, but I'm only arguing that 50,000 is near impossible here!)
- With a final price of 8,300 Bolivar, that gives us inflation of 16,500% from the 50 Bolivar coffee on Sep 26 2018. A very safe margin of error from 50,000%. Interestingly:
- Calculated from the starting point of 10 Bolivar, a final price of 8,300 would result in 82,900% inflation - but that would be across 15 months, not 12. As I write all this I fear I've completely missed something, or have an order of magnitude error. Happy to share the spreadsheet or have someone point out the errors of my thinking!
Free dollar devalued a bit today. We should have last week's results tomorrow.
26 000 since start of year. Given indirect link to real inflation etc. best guess is close to 50 000 for the year.

The free dollar keeps revaluing very 'slowly'. It seems that the owner of the cafeteria in Caracas is valuing the cup of coffee at about 90 cents of a dollar, and covered with a slightly higher price vs USD when increased price to BsS 6,500. She didn't have time to react this Monday and now she is about 4% short. If this very simplistic approach is correct, price will increase next week to BsS 7,500, or 36% in one month. There is no trustworthy sign of change in any other situation. Bottom line: hyperinflation is closer to 50,000% than to 100,000%.
A pack of chocolate can be exchanged with a gallon of gasoline...
Free dollar has revalued a 15% since end of May, projecting about 111,900% if prices double per month until end of September. Reducing the 500K% to 50K% and 100K%.

IMF forecasts that by the end of 2019 the inflation rate will be 1,000,000.
The Venezuelan Central Bank has said from 2016 to April 2019, the inflation was at 53.7m. At this point, unless something MAJOR changes in Venezuela, I can't see inflation dropping below 500,000.
Shifting to a band closer to 100,000% since the index is 81,000% right now.
Increased by Bs 1,000 on Jun 17th, 5% higher than the USD in the free market. Pushing on 50% per month, we would end around 50,525%, so reducing max and adding to >50k%.

Oct. 2018 price value is essentially zero. It’s not expected that recent currency adjustments will result in deflation. Therefore, at current pricing of ~5.5k, inflation of 91k% can be expected by target date. Given trend of reduction of rate and political-economic measures being implemented and considered, it can be expected that pricing will remain relatively stable while adjustments are continued to be made. No expectation of future acceleration of inflation is anticipated.
Respecting @nigster take. Lower crude oil prices likely keeping lid on inflation.

USD in free market revalued by 7% MTD (which is an estimate but an indicator that is not crazy). While we wait for the next café con leche price review, it seems still moderate. We should pay attention to the new many-zeros bills the government printed, though.

The time frame of the question is from 26 Sept 2018 to 25 Sept 2019 and at the start of that period the price of a single cup of coffee at Cafe Con Leche was 50 bolívars, therefore the bucket boundaries for the price of a coffee on 25 Sept 2019 are; 50,000% 25,000 bolívars
100,000% 50,000 bolívars
200,000% 100,000 bolívars
500,000% 250,000 bolívars The current price of a coffee is 5,500 bolívars so unless inflation takes off again in the next 3 months, the annual rate will be comfortably in the lowest bucket. This index roughly looks like a yoy price change of a cup of Cafe Con Leche (right now its 5500, compared to 6 a year ago or the 91567%).  By Sep 25 of last year, that cup has risen to 50 Bolivars.   If the price stays below 25000 in the next 3 months (i.e. ~5x) then the <50k % will win.  Similarly, if it goes to 25-50k, then the 2nd option would be correct.   I don't have a strong view on "how much worse" things will get but I think some where in the 5-10x in the next 3 months seems the most likely.  If the general 100x rise in prices per year keeps up, then we could expect ~3-4x in the next quarter, putting us near 20k barring anything really dramatic happening.

50000% is very high and the rate seems to be declining. 90000-ish% currently over the past year and declining at smaller time intervals closer to the present. I do not have information or knowledge about other events that are expected to occur between now and September. Due to this I’ll put most of my confidence say 75% in the under 50k% bin with decreasing amounts in higher bins.

According to Bloomberg's Café con Leche index, the cost of a café con leche increased from 5.50 bolivars on June 6, 2018 to 5,500 bolivars (an increase of 99,900 percent) as of June 6, 2019. It is very likely that the inflation rate will continue to increase given that the economic crisis is ongoing and little has been done to abate it. However, the price of a café con leche has remained at 5,500 for 5 weeks now, which is the longest a price has remained stable in the past year. In addition, further developments involving Juan Guaido may cause regime change or help strengthen the markers. However, it is very unlikely that the inflation rate will drop below 100,000 percent or exceed 200,000 percent within the next three months.
Not sure everyone understands narrow focus of this question. It’s not about broader economy. It’s re a cup of coffee in a bakery in Caracas. For past six months 18 800% and fairly steady recently.
Following @Chrisp advice, it seems that the USD in the black (free) market has stabilized, so I move my prediction to "lower" inflation.

Currently over 500k%. Unlikely to improve in the short term, Venezuala is currently in default on its loans and has a miserable credit rating. The instability generated by the government's issuance of new currency is unlikely to change in the short term. The government's continued mismanagement of state-owned companies is contributing significantly as well, but in the current climate, it's unlikely that they will be replaced or change their practices. Most likely outcome - inflation continues to rise.
Inflation currently about 300k pc and should rise faster

A Dictator wont release power until he is dead unfortunately. Unless your currency is the basis that the world is set by printing unlimited fiat is ultimately a futile event. Power is inversely proportional to money. So a dictator thinks that the more money he has the more power he has. So if his power starts to wane he prints more money to even the balance. As his power continues to wane he prints more fiat to make up for his declining power. Power is actually directly proportionate to belief. If someone actual believes in you they will give themselves over to you.

Looks like the Venezuelan government has published inflation figures. They had not done so in 4 years. http://www.bcv.org.ve/estadisticas/consumidor# The IMF forecast is 10,000,000% inflatino by the end of 2019. 
The Venezuelan Central Bank projects inflation will ease and that monthly increases are now about 30% in comparison to 200% at the start of the year.

Bloomberg also reports a slowdown due to the Maduro regime forcing banks to hoard cash that people would otherwise use to buy dollars on the black market.  The most recent Bloomberg Cafe con Leche forecast shows the annual inflation rate to be 99,900%.
FT noted inflation hit 130,000% as per the country's central bank.
https://www.ft.com/content/5cb83c1c-821b-11e9-b592-5fe435b57a3b
"Cafe Con Leche Index" equivalent in the USA would be what? "Big Mac Index"?

Getting inflation under control in Venezuela is likely to require the involvement of the international community, and yet the international community seems to be distancing themselves from the Maduro government.  So, any plan to address hyperinflation is likely to require a change in leadership, with a plan taking at least a few months to implement.  The crowd forecast for a Maduro departure by the end of September 2019 is currently at 16% [1]. Given the lead time to implement a plan, I've discounted the chance of bringing inflation under control (< 50k%) to 10%. Without a plan, I would expect hyperinflation to continue, although I have no idea how to forecast what range that will be in.   The current Cafe Con Leche Index places the price at 5,500 new bolivars, unchanged for the past four readings in the month of May.  The Index calculated inflation at just under 100k%.  However, the IMF is forecasting 2019 inflation rate of 10 million per cent [2]. Without a plan, I would expect inflation rates to continue to rise from current levels, and possibly accelerate. Thanks also to @Chema_Soloregistro for teh useful links. [3] [1] https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1064-when-will-nicolas-maduro-cease-to-be-president-of-venezuela
[2] https://www.imf.org/en/Countries/VEN
[3] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/868005
I will check this question again if things change much in June but right now it seems the rate of growth has leveled off.

These estimates for inflation are frankly absurd. 1 million % by the IMF puts all of Western economics and science in question.  Venezuela's 2018 Inflation to Hit 1.37 Million Percent, IMF Says
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-10-09/venezuela-s-2018-inflation-to-hit-1-37-million-percent-imf-says The actual current situation appears to be The Venezuelan Central Bank changed course in December, aggressively devaluing the Bolivar with respect to the dollar in the official DICOM foreign currency auctions until it overtook the black market rate in late January, at around 3,300 BsS per dollar. Both rates hovered around this value until late April, when the black market surged and the official exchange rate followed suit, being set at 5,200 BsS per dollar. This BCV policy, along with measures to restrict the amount of Bolivars, has been credited for slowing down the economy’s inflationary spiral, with inflation registered at 18,1 and 44,7 percent in March and April, respectively, according to the opposition-controlled National Assembly’s finance commission. 
https://venezuelanalysis.com/news/14479 Venezuela: Maduro Announces Economic Reforms Including Monetary Reconversion, Tax Breaks & Currency Control Changes
https://venezuelanalysis.com/news/13967 Looks like the economic reforms worked in braking the inflation rate to a more manageable 40-50% montly inflation rate. Hyperinflation "contained" in March Event Consumer prices grew by 18.1% month on month in March, after monthly inflation of 53.7% in February, according to data from the National Assembly, the legislature
http://country.eiu.com/article.aspx?articleid=187955802&Country=Venezuela&topic=Economy&subtopic=Forecast&subsubtopic=Inflation&linkId=100000006072230

According to Austrian Economics, inflation is the rate at fiat-money is increasing in the economy. For other economic schools, it measures the devaluation of money.
Having this concept in mind, Venezuela's government can keep on printing money to sustain it's expenses for some time. If there is no political change, the rate of inflation might be somewhat around the recent months, witch is higher than 2018 numbers. So, we expect a higher inflation for 2019.

Café con Leche index measuring just one item: a "relaxing" cup of café con leche in a bakery in eastern Caracas. Current value 144,637%. Café con Leche's value on Sept 26th 2018: VEF 50.00. Staying as they are, the annual inflation rate would be 10,900% on Sept 25th 2019. There is certain pattern (with such a small sample) in the price of the cup, about doubling after being unchanged for 3 or 4 weeks, kind of changing prices by the end of every month. This does not need to be the case, but using this pattern, it will double again 4 or 5 times before Sept 25th. That would take the rate to 175,900% or 351,900%. Hyperinflation situation has been very well described by The Economist here [1]. It is "a monetary phenomenon, with printing presses running nonstop", (SPOILER ALERT) Money Heist type [3], due to a "politically unmanegable fiscal burden" [1]. Same article mentions that hyperinflation can end in a question of weeks, if a "credible policy shift" occurs: "sustainable fiscal consolidation, […] credible pledge to stop funding [by printing money] and commitment to a new monetary framework". "New political leadership often helps, as does external financial support". On the question, I set some % for such a simple rate being manipulated (to go down), a 10% chance.
Assuming it is not, we do have some forecasts from the IMF [2] which puts it at 10^6 % at year end, but IMF figures have been questioned by academics [4]. A discouraging note: "The IMF and the press are clearly unaware of the fact that hyperinflation can be measured, and measured very accurately, but it cannot be forecasted" [4]. But this is Good Judgment anyway, so I'll give it a try: how likely is the "credible policy shift" to happen, and if so, will it have time before Sept 25th to reduce significantly?
- Maduro (or similar) continues ruling the country, unable to access the funds from oil, only supported by Russia and maybe China, and with the need to "buy" the military's support. In this case, hyperinflation could reach 500,000% or more. While I really wish this happens soon, reality checks and Guaidó lacks the trust of the Venezuelan people. This is the reason it takes so long to the inevitable change of regime. Sadly, only 50% chance it happens before August and split 25/75 below and higher 500,000%, weight on the lose of trust in the currency creating a vicious circle.
- Government changes by August, 50% chance, measures are implemented, external financial support will come, petro-dollars flow again and trust is regained. It's a question of weeks, as per The Economist [1], and other cases show that disinflation can be experienced quickly [5]. 50% for less than 50,000% and 50% in the 200,000% (short time). "For long-suffering Venezuelans, that cannot come too soon" [1] [1] https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2019/01/31/hyperinflations-can-end-quickly-given-the-right-sort-of-regime-change
[2] https://www.imf.org/external/datamapper/PCPIPCH@WEO/WEOWORLD/VEN
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Money_Heist
[4] https://www.forbes.com/sites/stevehanke/2018/07/31/imf-produces-another-bogus-venezuela-inflation-forecast/#42f768c47dc8
[5] https://www.forbes.com/sites/stevehanke/2019/01/16/zimbabwes-monetary-death-spiral/#4fc5eedc35e7
